audio_caption: The audio clip opens with enthusiastic applause and cheering, transitioning into upbeat rock music, probably played by a band. A male speaker begins speaking in a complimentary tone. He says "you look sensational", and goes on to praise the woman's earrings. The woman responds in a pleasant tone.  The man congratulates her on the show Vikings.

The audio clip features two speakers, one male and one female, discussing a popular television show. The female speaker mentions having "just read the numbers" regarding the show's ratings, followed by the male speaker who expresses disbelief, saying "Isn't that crazy?" He compares the show's popularity to "American Idol," suggesting a humorous and exaggerated preference for "large women fighting." Laughter follows, presumably in response to the joke.

The scene opens with enthusiastic clapping, followed by a female speaker expressing approval with "kickass woman power." A male speaker responds affirmatively and asks if she engages in martial arts, imitating sounds of fighting. She confirms her martial arts training from a young age, starting with her first black belt at thirteen, and starting her first school at sixteen, noting she grew up in a Taekwondo gym. The male speaker then asks if men find her abilities intimidating or strangely attractive. The female speaker laughs, and the male speaker admits to finding her abilities intimidating but also strangely attractive. She explains that it's unexpected for most people, and states she’s been looking for a role where she can use martial arts. The male speaker responds affirmatively.

A woman is telling a story about teaching taekwondo at night and preparing students for their black belts. A man chimes in and makes a joke, and she laughs. The woman then recounts an incident where she was depositing checks at an ATM in what she describes as not the best part of Toronto, where she saw a group of guys hanging out at a coffee shop nearby. The man interjects, hyperbolically describing Toronto as a "jungle." He compliments her leg movement, acknowledging her skill as a black belt. She downplays it modestly, and she begins to continue the story. Then the man interrupts to ask if she was jumped by Canadians.

The clip begins with a female speaker recounting a startling experience at an ATM. She describes how the door suddenly opened and two people rushed towards her, mimicking their actions with sounds. A male voice interrupts, calling her name with surprise. The female speaker acknowledges a friend was involved, but the male speaker expresses disbelief, questioning why friends would approach her in such a manner at night, calling it "stupid." The woman agrees, stating that's what she told them. The male speaker continues by referencing her ability to fight. The male speaker comments on her yell, then says, "but you can't run up to any woman like that at night", which would be "terrifying" for "or man, for example." The female speaker agrees.

The clip begins with a male voice, characterized by a somewhat questioning tone. This is followed by a female voice with a more confident tone, who states that the show "Vikings" is "based on a real character." She mentions that the creator of the show also worked on "Tudors" and "Elizabeth," and that he consulted with a historian to "try to make it as accurate as possible."

The audio clip begins with a female speaker, presenting with an excited and enthusiastic tone, describing someone named Lagertha as a "real kick-ass woman who can actually fight." She emphasizes Lagertha's amazing qualities based on her research. A male speaker then responds, asking if Lagertha is a real person. The female speaker confirms that Lagertha is a real shieldmaiden, describing the character as a "fierce, strong woman" who goes to battle with men and fights alongside them during shield walls.

The clip starts with two speakers, a woman and a man. The woman enthusiastically confirms the existence of female warriors in the Dark Ages. The man expresses his excitement about Viking ships arriving with both men and women, marveling at the idea of female Viking warriors. As the man expresses his enthusiasm with "Wow, I love this," there is an energetic battle cry, followed by the man's positive reaction. The conversation continues as he speculates about his people's interactions with the Vikings. The woman clarifies that he is Scottish, and he confirms, before asking where the woman is from, and she says they shot in Ireland.

The audio clip starts with a female speaker identifying herself as from "Toronto, Canada" with a Ukrainian heritage, speaking in a conversational tone. A male voice then responds, mentioning "Ukraine" and a humorous misinterpretation of "Toronto, Canada", delivered with a playful tone. The woman then speaks in Ukrainian, seemingly responding to the misinterpretation. The male then responds in Ukrainian, which he admits he just "made that up." Then the female speaks in Ukrainian saying "I see your beautiful hair, I say it is very beautiful, I love it, I can now kill you". The male speaker states "I don't care what" and begins to laugh. The male speaker states "I don't even know if I want to know what it means because it means a whole lot to me". He then says, "You're an expert at this talk show thing. Have you done it a lot?"

The audio begins with a brief, enthusiastic "No, it's my first one," followed by a lighthearted, teasing response, "You kidding me." Someone then exclaims, "I'm popping." An interjection of "Sacré bleu" occurs, succeeded by a burst of laughter, including what sounds like nervous giggling. Someone states, "Very nerve-racking." The tone shifts to conversational as someone remarks on "Air condition is fixed." There is a chuckle at this. "Well good for you then" is stated. Laughter continues. Someone then asks if one is back in Ukraine a lot. One states that they didn't get a chance to go there again. A Viking reference is made. Someone notes that Vikings went everywhere and were navigators, totally kicking ass. Someone comments, "For reasons which will become clear later they were never in America." The speaker then notes that they know that, prompting a laugh from the others. The Viking Eric the Red is referenced. Someone notes that there is a story about the first Viking tribe played by Travis Fimmel is amazing and the first to navigate and explore the West. A mention of going to Toronto is then stated. "Probably went to Toronto," one quips. One then states, "Probably in that very strip mall that you were in," and someone comments that he could have killed those guys. "We're out of time" is stated.

The clip starts with a male speaker complimenting someone's performance, followed by another female speaker responding. The male speaker then humorously asks her not to applaud, saying it distracts him. He expresses that her Ukrainian sounds during the earlier bit felt wasted. The female speaker jokingly offers to repeat it later. The male speaker then pivots the conversation, suggesting activities like playing frisbee with a horse or playing the "mouth organ." The female speaker is enthusiastic about the "mouth organ." The male speaker is hesitant and then asks if she is sure about this, but goes ahead and offers the mouth organ. He asks if she's musical, and he's reassuring. At the end of the conversation, he mentions they're going to a commercial break and then he adds, "We'll be right back." Then there's a musical interlude with a carnival type vibe. This song features a trombone melody, and it sounds playful and a little quirky.
